translation.en: Things will never be the same without him, huh?
No.
Our people, uh...
I know they don't get along that good.
They'll be okay.
Uh, Frankie. I know you don't like me because the commission passed you over.
translation.ko: 프랭크, 윗선에서 널 제껴서 못마땅한 거 알아

translation.en: You being my brother's underboss,
you think you should have been the next in line. I understand that.
As a matter of fact, I like you, Aldo.
You're just not qualified to be a boss.
You're a bean counter.
You belong on Wall Street, not with us.
What are you trying to say?
Everything's money with you, Aldo.
translation.ko: 자넨 돈밖에 모르는 속물이야 이 세계의 의리를 모르지

translation.en: You got no respect for our thing.
You got no soul.
That's why your brother, Sally Boy, rest in peace,
never gave you more than his taxes to do every year.
Yeah? Well, I'm the boss now.
And you better make sure your people keep in line.
Don't worry about my people.
But you better worry about yours.
[mutters] Yeah.
Hey, boss.
Jimmy, what do you hear, what do you say?
Couple of those FBI guys were in here.
They left a card.
- Oh, yeah? - Golf buddies of yours?
They're trying to convince me my life's in danger.
[Jimmy] You?
You're the only guy I know whose life isn't in danger.
translation.ko: 이 세계에 보스만큼 속 편한 사람이 어딨어요

translation.en: And everybody I know, everybody loves Frankie the Fixer.
translation.ko: 해결사 프랭키라면 다들 두 팔 벌려 환영이죠

translation.en: Eh, tell me about it.
I'm gonna give you the cocksucker,
but I got some demands.
For starters, I don't want to relocate in the US.
It ain't safe around here no more.
Then what are you thinking? Sun bed in the Bahamas?
Nah.
Melanoma's for the old-school wiseguys.
translation.ko: 피부암 걸리게 그런 촌스러운 짓 안 해

translation.en: I'm thinking Lilyhammer.
Lily what?
[woman] I think it's in Sweden. Close enough.
Why the fuck would you want to go there?
Didn't you see the Olympics in '94?
It was beautiful.
Clean air, fresh white snow, gorgeous broads,
translation.ko: 깨끗한 공기, 새하얀 눈 여자들도 죽여주고

translation.en: and best of all, nobody but nobody's gonna be looking for me there.
translation.ko: 그런 건 둘째 치고 거기선 쫓길 일 없잖아

translation.en: Listen, you give us Aldo Delucci,
and we'll send you to the goddamn North Pole.
You got a deal.
[woman on radio] Just minutes ago, the district attorney's prime witness,
translation.ko: 조금 전 검사 측 핵심 증인이자

translation.en: former underboss Frank "The Fixer" Tagliano,
gave a shattering testimony against his boss, Aldo Delucci.
translation.ko: 보스인 알도 델루치에 관한 충격적인 증언을 했습니다

translation.en: Inside sources say Tagliano is the last person
anyone would have expected to testify.
translation.ko: 모든 진실을 아는 마지막 측근이었다고 합니다

translation.en: [man] Now, sports with Mike Mitchell...
Look, here's the file to your new identity,
and the address to your new house.
We had to give you a backstory with a Norwegian father.
From now on, you're Giovanni Henriksen.
You're a restaurant owner with no criminal record.
[stammers] Hangrinsen?
You couldn't find a more complicated name?
translation.ko: 더 복잡한 이름을 못 찾았나 보지?

translation.en: If you get into any, and I mean any trouble with the police,
you are on your own.
Don't worry about a thing.
I'm a brand-new guy over here.
Yeah, right.
[woman speaking Norwegian on headphones] Hello.
How are you?
I am fine.
How about you?
Hi.
My name is Kari.
What is your name?
Chapter Nine: Shopping.
Sorry, we are sold out of bread.
That's okay... [voice fades]
[man 1] Not so good-looking? [man 2] She was at least 30 years old.
- Could you please turn it down? - [man 1] Like this?
- [older man] Please, turn it off. - [man 1] Jerk!
- Hey. - Give me my cap back. Give me my cap back.
[in English] Do I have your attention? Just nod.
Yeah. This is what happens next:
You're gonna go out there, you're gonna give the man his hat back,
and you're gonna shut that shit off. Yes?
- Yes. - Here's your fucking hanky.
Go do the right thing.
- [in Norwegian] Turn the music off. - [music stops]
Sorry.
- Okay? - Okay
- [man 2 mutters insult] - Shut up.
So, straight to the asylum reception center, I take it?
[in English] Excuse me?
[in Norwegian] Oh, you don't speak Norwegian?
[in English] Uh... Just a little bit.
[in Norwegian] I just thought you looked a little Arab.
[in English] You look a little Arabish in the face.
Well, I'm an American.
[in Norwegian] An American? What the hell are you doing in Lillehammer?
[in English] Tell you the truth, I fell in love with your Olympics.
[in Norwegian] Ah, those were the days. I wasn't sober until February, 1995.

translation.en: [in English] I wasn't sober until one year after.

[in English] Here we are.
- That place? - Yep.
[in Norwegian] So, that'll be 273 kroner.
[in English] Are you sure that's the house?
Yes, sir. [in Norwegian] This is it.
[in English] Here you go. Keep the change, all right?
[in Norwegian] Shit, thanks a lot.
[in English] Welcome to Lillehammer.
This one's for you, Lily.

translation.en: The answer can be found in...
- [alarm beeping loudly] - [man speaking Norwegian on radio]
...and again there has been an unwanted guest in the Lillehammer area.

[in Norwegian] How are you?
[in English] What the fuck...
- [in Norwegian] There it is! - [in English] Excuse me?
[in Norwegian] It is my sheep head. It must have fallen out of the bag.

translation.en: [in English] I'm sorry, I don't understand.
Oh, the sheep head, it's my dinner.

Well, for a minute there,
I thought I was going to have to give Johnny Fontane a movie part.
[chuckles awkwardly] Okay. You must be the new neighbor.
- Laila Hovland. - Hi. Giovanni Hankrensen.
Hankrensen? Is that Indian or...
[stammering] No, it's Henriksen.
My father was Norwegian.
[in Norwegian] He was Norwegian.
So you understand Norwegian?
- [Laila laughing] - [in English] Call me Johnny.

translation.en: - Johnny. - Oh, you're in the postal service, huh?

I'm chief of police.
[in Norwegian] So, you'll sleep safely here.
- Oh... - [in English] See you around! [in Norwegian] See you, Johnny!
Okay...
What the fuck?
Fuckin' amateurs.
How are you doing?
- Giovanni Henriksen? - Yes.
So...
You lived in New York all your life?
That's right.
♪ Start spreading the news ♪
[chuckling] I was there once, you know. The Big Apple.
- That's good. - Yeah.
And you have some background from the restaurant business?
Yeah.
[in Norwegian] There are not many jobs available now.
There's not very much here... A delivery job at Dolly Dimple's.
[in English] Pizza delivery.
I had a very successful bar in New York, you know.
So I know all about it.
I just need you to make a few moves so I can get a local license, that's all.

translation.en: [in Norwegian] We need to have a reality check.
[in English] We have to have some reality check here, you know?
To start a bar is a very complicated process.
Oh, complications. That's what you call it here?
Same thing where I come from.
I brought a little something for that purpose.
Take care of whoever you gotta take care of.
[in Norwegian] Excuse me, but are you attempting to bribe a public official?
[in English] No. It's just so everybody can wet their beak a little bit.
- Do you want me to call the police? - What?
Should I pick up the phone and call the police?
Easy, take it easy.
All right, maybe you do things differently here.
- Yeah. - I apologize.
Okay.
Maybe we should put this on the account for cultural differences?
Cultural differences.
[in Norwegian] I think we'll start by enrolling you on a job-seeker course.
Starts Friday.
You turn up there with a slightly more humble attitude, and we'll start afresh.

See you on Friday.
- [in English] Thank you. - [in Norwegian] Bye.
[woman speaking Norwegian on headphones] Hello.
How are you?
Fine. And you?
I have new mittens.
How about you?
[in English] What the fuck?
Little lamb,
what are you doing out here by yourself?
All right. Take it easy.
Take it easy.
- [sheep bleating] - Where you going? Come here!
[man speaking Norwegian on TV] But in languages,
not only linguistics and research are important.

translation.en: Do you think the wolf killed my sheep?
No, Jonas, don't think like that.

translation.en: Everything will be fine.
I couldn't see any footprints of predators.
Dad?
Do you know anyone who drives an electric car?

Uh... Come, come.
[whispers] Put that away.

[Sigrid in Norwegian] It is an escaped sheep.
- Hi, I'm Sigrid. - [in English] Oh, hi.
We never said hello on the train.
Yeah, yeah. Giovanni. Call me Johnny.
[Sigrid in Norwegian] Now you are happy, Jonas.
You...
Thanks a lot for finding her.

- That's a nice kid you got there. - Yeah.
Father around? I'd like to meet him.
Uh... No, he's not living here.
Well, small town. Maybe we'll run into each other again, you know?
- Yeah. - Have a little coffee.
Okay. Thank you.

Eight people. Very good.
Today we are going to have a look at some forms.
You are disturbing us.
What Giovanni is doing here,
is breaking the first rule of the workplace,

translation.en: namely, being punctual.
So, I see there are some regulars here.
That's always nice. Hi, Maria.
Those among you who were at the motivation seminar

translation.en: held at my cabin last year know that I am a fishing enthusiast.
translation.ko: 참석했던 분들도 있네요 다들 아시겠지만 전 낚시광이죠

translation.en: And what I usually say is that getting a job is like fishing.
You have to put the line out to catch something.
It's time for you to meet a friend of mine. Arne.
Today, Arne is your employer, and you are going to a job interview.

translation.en: - [Arne] Am I... Sorry. - [Jan] Don't disturb me.
Um... Any volunteers?
Does anyone want to... Giovanni?
[in English] Come on, let's give it a shot. Yes, please.
Thank you.
[in Norwegian] Hi, Giovanni.
Why, exactly should we choose you?
[in English] Do I talk to you or talk to the dummy?
[in Norwegian] Talk to Arne.
Hi, Giovanni. Uh... What are your strong qualities?
[in English] My strong qualities? Uh...
I'd say observation's one of my finer qualities.
Observing you, I'd say you look a little stiff.
[in Norwegian] You can't have a little fun.
Let's take a little break.
Giovanni, could I have two minutes?
translation.ko: 죠반니 씨 잠깐 얘기 좀 할까요?

translation.en: [in English] Two minutes, please.
[in Norwegian] I'm going to transfer you over to a course called Fresh Start.
[in English] What's that?
It's a six-month daily course
for immigrants that struggle to adapt to Norwegian society.
Six months? You gotta be joking.
[in Norwegian] I never joke when it comes to integration, Giovanni. You need this.

translation.en: [in English] Wait a minute. Are you telling me
I gotta spend half a year learning how to be a fucking immigrant?

translation.en: [in Norwegian] You would perhaps rather have me call the police.
[in English] Do you want me to call the police, then? And tell them about the bribe?
- Okay. [sighs] - Okay.
Hey, mister. Mister.
Do you want to come for a beer? [in Norwegian] A Friday beer?

translation.en: [in English] With us?
Uh... No, thanks. I gotta pass. It's a big TV night.

translation.en: Sure, okay.
On second thought, one drink. What the hell.

How are you going to manage on that?
[in English] I only get 340 kroners per day from NAV.

I am talking about the system.
We haven't ordered anything.
From that table.

I am not so good at darts.

I'm not gonna be at NAV too long. I'm just getting some information.

translation.en: To teachers.

A hundred and fifty.

Good evening.

There wouldn't be anyone thinking of doing anything rash here?

[in Norwegian] I take it we're all fully aware of that.

[in Norwegian] Johansen's cabin.
I think it's in that area. We can spend the night there.
[man] What are you doing?

Fuck.
[in English] I found it.
[Torgeir in Norwegian] I know what we need now.
- Do you have it? - Yes.
- [in English] That's a good idea. - Yeah.
[chuckles] There's booze in that. Yes, homemade.
That's some Norwegian cuisine I could learn to love.
[in Norwegian] I'm hungry.
[in English] You should call room service.
What did you do, um... back in the States?
I had a restaurant, a little bar.
[in Norwegian] You seem to know a lot about guns and...
[in English] getting rid of evidence...

translation.en: [in English] You kiddin'?
You ever seen the Cooking Channel?
It can get pretty rough.
[in Norwegian] What the hell? What the hell?
Any naked ladies?
Yeah.
- [Roar laughs] - Johansen?
- Yeah. - [Roar in Norwegian] Look at him.
[Torgeir] Holy shit! Look at this.
She can't be more than 15, 16 years old.
I've driven her and her mom to school several times.

translation.en: [Torgeir] He works for the county.
[in English] Yeah, that's interesting.
- [in Norwegian] I am getting sick. - [Torgeir] Look at him!

translation.en: I am shocked!
This is serious business.
He works for the county.
Roar...
[in English] Look who's here.
Be cool, okay? Follow my lead.
Oh, hello.
[Laila in English] Hi.
[in Norwegian] Well, been on a long trip?
[in English] Just, uh, out enjoying your lovely scenery.
[in Norwegian] We've had a report about illegal hunting in this area.

translation.en: [in Norwegian] Wow!
- [in English] Illegal hunting, yeah? - Ah.
That's crazy.
[in Norwegian] We have a witness.
Supervisor Antonsen.
He saw illegal hunting in the Mesna hills yesterday.
translation.ko: 어제 메스나 언덕에서 늑대 잡는 걸 봤대요

translation.en: If you have something to say, it would be wise to do it now.
translation.ko: 할 말 있으면 지금 하는 게 좋을 거예요

translation.en: [in Norwegian] We were...
[in English] We don't really have anything to say because we didn't see anything.
translation.ko: 아무것도 못 봐서 할 말이 없네요

translation.en: [in Norwegian] Did you see these guys yesterday?
translation.ko: 어제 본 사냥꾼들 이 사람들 맞아요?

translation.en: No.
- Huh? - No?
The ones I saw were younger fellas.
[Laila] But you said you saw the Lien brothers.
[Antonsen] My eyesight clearly isn't as good as it used to be.
[Lailla] Isn't it, now?
The ones I saw must have been some youths from Oslo.
Youths from Oslo are the worst.
[in English] So, now that we've cleared up that little misunderstanding,
why don't we all go inside and have a drink?
[in Norwegian] Thank you, but we'd better be off.
[in English] Always good to help the authorities.
Especially when they're neighbors. [chuckles]
How ya doin'?
[in Norwegian] I don't think we have an appointment today.
[in English] I think we do.
[in Norwegian] If you think you can come charging in here with more bribes...

translation.en: [in English] Yeah, well, that's my appointment.
[in Norwegian] What's this?
But how have you got hold of these?
[in English] The real question is, what am I gonna do with them?
Is this blackmail?
Definitely.
Where I come from, these kind of pictures could be a problem for a public official,
but maybe that's just [mocking] cultural differences.

translation.en: Could be a problem here as well. Absolutely.
Okay.
How about I make the pictures disappear and you do a little something for me.

Yep.

Looks nice.
Good enough to own?
Of course it's good enough to own. [chuckles]
What do you think?
Well, I bought it.
I need a partner. I'm thinking about you.

[chuckles] Yep.
Take a look.

Nothing.
You sign at the bottom, then you're a bar owner.

[in English] You're not shitting me right now?

You bet your ass it's a yes.
Torgeir Lien.

Why don't you pour us a little celebration libation?
Sure, Giovanni.
Look at me, I'm a bar owner!
